briefing.opening: Good morning/afternoon, everyone. I will now begin the climate briefing for February 1, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ The Severe Reality of Climate Change and Its Domestic and International Impacts
sections.content: Today, numerous severe impacts of climate change and their resulting crisis signals have been reported both domestically and internationally. Domestically, ecological disturbances such as the earlier hatching of penguins due to climate change have been observed [1], and extreme weather events are directly impacting our daily lives, for instance, with croaker fish (Gulbi) appearing on Lunar New Year tables [9]. Internationally, climate change is limiting future Olympic host cities [29], and in the United States, winter storms caused by global warming are putting disaster response systems to the test [32, 33], increasing the intensity and unpredictability of disasters. Furthermore, invisible changes in precipitation are significantly increasing flood risks [34], and households in Illinois continue to bear the costs of climate change damage [31], leading to discussions about compensation for climate damage from fossil fuel companies [36]. Amidst these circumstances, voices are also emerging that claim bias in federal reference materials on climate change [30], further emphasizing the importance of accurate information dissemination.

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Domestic Carbon Neutrality Policies and Adaptation Efforts
sections.content: Domestically, local governments and businesses are actively pursuing efforts to respond to climate change and achieve carbon neutrality goals. Yeosu City has confirmed the hosting of 'UNFCCC Climate Week' [3, 7], which will establish a forum for international discussions on climate action. Gyeongsangbuk-do is also strengthening joint efforts with related organizations to respond to climate change and achieve carbon neutrality goals [4]. Climate change adaptation and urban environmental improvement projects are also taking shape, such as Sangju City's full-scale river maintenance project in 2026 [6] and Suwon City's inspection of the Gosaek-dong Carbon Neutral Green City development project [16]. Furthermore, Chungcheongbuk-do has published a glossary to enhance residents' understanding of carbon neutrality policies [11, 18], and Jeju City is expanding the introduction of electric low-floor buses [12, 17], thereby encouraging citizen participation and practicing carbon reduction in daily life. Hyundai Steel has demonstrated corporate climate leadership by achieving a 'Leadership A-' rating in the CDP Climate Change Response category [5]. Diverse approaches are also being explored, including calls for mandatory Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) for carbon neutrality in buildings [10] and the presentation of alternative landscapes through a Harvard University exhibition [8].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Accelerating Renewable Energy Transition and Industrial Innovation
sections.content: The transition to renewable energy, essential in the era of climate change, is accelerating domestically. The Ministry of Climate has announced plans to focus all its capabilities on achieving the goal of supplying 100 gigawatts (GW) of renewable energy by 2030 [19, 26]. Local governments and related organizations, including Gyeongsangbuk-do and Daegu Regional Environmental Office, are signing business agreements to expand renewable energy supply and contribute to regional economic revitalization [20, 21, 23]. Efforts such as holding the Rural Renewable Energy Plan Forum to secure energy sovereignty are also continuing [22]. In the industrial sector, in line with carbon neutrality regulations, the Korean shipbuilding industry is rebounding through LNG carrier construction [14], and a 'great transformation' of the energy machinery industry is beginning, with the full-scale development of ultra-large wind power, Small Modular Reactors (SMRs), and power grid technologies [24]. Private sector investment in renewable energy is also active, with companies like GS E&C expanding their energy business by signing a solar PPA (Power Purchase Agreement) with LG U+ [25, 27].

sections.title: ğŸŒ International Community's Climate Response Efforts and Financial Trends
sections.content: Responding to climate change is impossible without international cooperation and financial support, and positive movements have been observed in these aspects. In Japan, a concentration of investment in 'resilience bonds' for climate change response has been observed [2], indicating growing market interest in strengthening climate resilience. Domestically, KB Financial Group has established the 'KB Deep Tech Scale-up Fund' worth 1,600ì–µ ì› to support deep technology innovation companies [28], which can serve as a crucial nutrient for the development and dissemination of climate technologies. Furthermore, internationally, companies like Centara Maldives are actively responding to climate change [35], demonstrating that private sector participation is driving global climate action.

briefing.closing: Today's briefing has highlighted the urgency of climate change, as well as the diverse domestic and international efforts being made to address it. Through continued attention and cooperation, we must work towards building a more sustainable future. This concludes the climate briefing for February 1, 2026.

articles.title: KB Financial Group Establishes 160 Billion Won Fund to Support Deep Tech Companies
articles.original_title: KBê¸ˆìœµ, ë”¥í…Œí¬ ê¸°ì—… ì§€ì› 1600ì–µì› í€ë“œ ê²°ì„±
articles.description: KB Financial Group announced on the 1st that it has established the 'KB Deep Tech Scale-up Fund' to support deep tech innovation companies and will begin providing venture capital. The fund, totaling 160 billion won, was raised with 75 billion won from the Korea Venture Investment Corporation (Mother Fund) and 85 billion won from KB Financial Group affiliates. It will invest in 9 sectors including system semiconductors, bio-health, future mobility, eco-friendly energy, and robotics.

summary.phenomenon: KB Financial Group established the 160 billion won 'KB Deep Tech Scale-up Fund' on the 1st to support deep tech innovation companies. This fund was raised with contributions from the Korea Venture Investment Corporation (Mother Fund) and KB Financial Group affiliates.
summary.outlook: This fund is expected to invest in deep tech companies across 9 sectors, including system semiconductors, bio-health, future mobility, eco-friendly energy, and robotics.

articles.original_title: Fossil fuel firms may have to pay for climate damage under proposed UN tax
articles.description: Framework Convention on International Tax Cooperation could also force ultra-rich to pay global wealth tax Fossil fuel companies could be forced to pay some of the price of their damage to the climate, and the ultra-rich subjected to a global wealth tax, if new tax rules are agreed under the UN.Negotiations on a planned global tax treaty will resume at the UN headquarters in New York on Monday, with dozens of countries supporting stronger rules that would make polluters pay for the impact of the

summary.phenomenon: Fossil fuel companies have caused damage to the climate. Specific details regarding the nature of the damages, timing, locations, and figures were not mentioned in the article.
summary.cause: Climate damage resulted from the activities of fossil fuel companies. Specific scientific causes or background were not mentioned in the article.
summary.outlook: If new tax rules are agreed upon at the UN, fossil fuel companies may be required to pay for climate damages, and the ultra-rich could be subjected to a global wealth tax. Related negotiations are scheduled to resume on Monday at the UN headquarters in New York.
